thread.title: Egypt’s Queen Nefertiti: hidden doors in Tutankhamun tomb may lead to burial chambers
thread.title_full: Egypt’s Queen Nefertiti: hidden doors in Tutankhamun tomb may lead to burial chambers

author: Caroline Zielinski
title: Egypt’s Queen Nefertiti: hidden doors in Tutankhamun tomb may lead to burial chambers
text:
Video Image Recreating Tutankhamun's tomb with 3D Printing 5:12 Take a look at how the University of Oxford has recreated Tutankhamun's tomb with 3D Printing. Courtesy: University of Oxford
August 30th 2015 2 months ago /video/video.news.com.au/Technology/ Where is she? ... A 3,300-year-old bust of Queen Nefertiti — whose burial place remains a mystery — stands on its socle at the New Museum in Berlin, Germany. Picture: AP /Markus Schreiber
Caroline Zielinski News Corp Australia Network THE first search of Egyptian Pharaoh Tutankhamun’s famous tomb has revealed hidden doors which could be the burial chambers of his heretic mother, Queen Nefertiti.
The tomb was searched for the first time yesterday by a team of experts and dignitaries, led by British archeologist Dr Nicholas Reeves, whose academic paper titled The Burial of Nefertiti , published in late July, quickly grabbed international attention for its claim that Queen Nefertiti was buried in a secret compartment of her son’s tomb.
Soon after the paper’s release, Egypt’s minister of antiquities, Mamdouh Eldamaty, invited the University of Arizona academic to prove his idea that the remains of the famous heretic Queen Nefertiti are hidden behind a wall in Tutankhamun’s burial chamber.
Mystery ... The golden sarcophagus of King Tutankhamun in his burial chamber. British Egyptologist Nicholas Reeves, who believes the legendary Queen Nefertiti may be buried in a secret room adjoining Tutankhamun's tomb arrived in Egypt, tested his theory on Monday. Picture: AFP / KHALED DESOUKI Source: AFP
According to Egyptian news service Ahram Online , yesterday’s expedition revealed scratchings and markings on the tomb’s northern and western walls, similar to those found on the entrance gate of Tutankhamun’s tomb when it was discovered in 1922.
“This indicates that the western and northern walls of Tutankhamun’s tomb could hide two burial chambers,” Mr Eldamaty told Ahram Online.
EXPLORE FURTHER: Is the tomb of Nefertiti hidden in plain sight?
PREPARATION: The search for Queen Nefertiti’s lost tomb
Dr Reeves said the findings also revealed the tomb’s ceiling extended behind the northern and western walls, another sign supporting his theory regarding the existence of two undiscovered chambers.
“After our first examination of the walls, we can do nothing more until we receive the all-clear from the radar device to confirm the our findings,” Dr Reeves said.
Boy king ... The gold mask of King Tutankhamun in a glass case during a press tour, in the Egyptian Museum near Tahrir Square, Cairo, Egypt. Picture: AP /Hassan Ammar Source: AP
In contrast to popular scholarship, which says that the painting located on the northern wall of Tutankhamun’s tomb shows king Ay doing the ritual for Tutankhamun — Dr Reeves believes that the picture depicts Tutankhamun himself completing a death ritual for Nefertiti.
“I am pretty sure that a very important discovery is to be made soon inside Tutankhamun’s tomb,” Dr Reeves said.
Minister Eldamaty said the radar scans of the two walls will be announced on November 4, the same day Tutankhamun’s tomb was discovered so long ago.
Dr Reeves said that digital photos taken of by art organisation Factume in order to reconstruct a replica tomb of Tutankhamun revealed the extended ceiling, traces of two doorways and royal stamps.
However, Mr Eldamaty said that while he believed in the existence of the hidden chambers, he doubted they would hold Queen Nefertiti’s remains.
“I am very enthusiastic about this work and I’m sure something is going to be discovered behind those two controversial walls,” Eldamaty said.
